Posted By: Guest1515973801 (4/26/2013 5:15:49 AM)

posts.post_content:
For those interested in the probabilities and how to find them...  
  
Consider 5 slots in which a coin can be placed heads or tails:  
\_\_ \_\_ \_\_ \_\_ \_\_  
  
How many different ways can you place a single heads?  
H T T T T  
T H T T T  
T T H T T  
T T T H T  
T T T T H = 5.  
  
How many different ways can you place two heads?  
H H T T T  
H T H T T  
H T T H T  
H T T T H  
T H H T T  
T H T H T  
T H T T H  
T T H H T  
T T H T H  
T T T H H = 10. This is equivalent to the combinatorial function n C k in the case of 5 C 2 (or 5 choose 2).  
  
Also, the cominatorial function n C k is defined as:  
n C k = n!/(k! \* (n-k)!)  
  
Oh, and n! means n \* (n-1) \* (n-2) \* (n-3) \* ... \* 1. It's the factorial function.  
  
So, we'll avoid calculating the rest by writing them out.  
5 C 0 = 1 (How many ways can you choose no heads? Just one.)  
5 C 1 = 5  
5 C 2 = 10  
5 C 3 = 10 (5 C 2 = 5 C 3, just imagine choosing two tails instead of three heads)  
5 C 4 = 5  
5 C 5 = 1 (There's only one way to have all heads.)  
  
Now that we know each different way the event ... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)
posts.html:
For those interested in the probabilities and how to find them...

Consider 5 slots in which a coin can be placed heads or tails:
__ __ __ __ __

How many different ways can you place a single heads?
H T T T T
T H T T T
T T H T T
T T T H T
T T T T H = 5.

How many different ways can you place two heads?
H H T T T
H T H T T
H T T H T
H T T T H
T H H T T
T H T H T
T H T T H
T T H H T
T T H T H
T T T H H = 10. This is equivalent to the combinatorial function n C k in the case of 5 C 2 (or 5 choose 2).

Also, the cominatorial function n C k is defined as:
n C k = n!/(k! * (n-k)!)

Oh, and n! means n * (n-1) * (n-2) * (n-3) * ... * 1. It's the factorial function.

So, we'll avoid calculating the rest by writing them out.
5 C 0 = 1 (How many ways can you choose no heads? Just one.)
5 C 1 = 5
5 C 2 = 10
5 C 3 = 10 (5 C 2 = 5 C 3, just imagine choosing two tails instead of three heads)
5 C 4 = 5
5 C 5 = 1 (There's only one way to have all heads.)

Now that we know each different way the event ... (see all)

Posted By: Jake1991 (4/23/2013 7:05:52 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
Coin flipping is making a comeback now it seems...  
  
Honestly, this is one of the most powerful planeswalkers printed since [Liliana of the Veil](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Liliana of the Veil). Grixis just got a huge boost of power from Ral, with the ability to contribute to both controls styles with his plus ability and his ultimate, and his first minus contributes well to Grixis aggro (his other abilities do as well). My only gripe with him is that after seeing him at the pre-release against me twice, I feel like he gets out too early with only being 2UR, when I would've rather seen him be either 3UR or stay 2UR and only have three loyalty counters to enter play.   
  
Awesome planeswalker. I can't wait to get my hands on one.
posts.html:
Coin flipping is making a comeback now it seems...

Honestly, this is one of the most powerful planeswalkers printed since Liliana of the Veil. Grixis just got a huge boost of power from Ral, with the ability to contribute to both controls styles with his plus ability and his ultimate, and his first minus contributes well to Grixis aggro (his other abilities do as well). My only gripe with him is that after seeing him at the pre-release against me twice, I feel like he gets out too early with only being 2UR, when I would've rather seen him be either 3UR or stay 2UR and only have three loyalty counters to enter play.

Awesome planeswalker. I can't wait to get my hands on one.

posts.post_content:
The probabilities are here, in case anyone was wondering:  
  
0 heads: 3.125% /// At least: 1 head: 96.875%  
1 head: 15.625% ///// 2 heads: 81.25%  
2 heads: 31.25% ///// 3 heads: 50%  
3 heads: 31.25% ////// 4 heads: 18.75%  
4 heads: 15.625%  
5 heads: 3.125%  
  
With Krark's Thumb:  
  
0 heads: .09767% /// At least: 1 head: 99.90233%  
1 head: 1.465% ///// 2 heads: 98.437%  
2 heads: 8.7891% ////// 3 heads: 89.648%  
3 heads: 26.367% ////// 4 heads: 63.281%  
4 heads: 39.551%  
5 heads: 23.73%  
  
Also, if you are running this card in casual, I recommend Contagion Engine with its +1 ability.  
  
Edit: Im sorry for the wrong percentages. I made an error inputting the percentage of winning with a coin flip.

posts.post_content:
This guy is custom made for decks that are playing artifact accelerants like [Izzet Signet](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Izzet Signet) and [Everflowing Chalice](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Everflowing Chalice) as well as pingers like [Izzet Staticaster](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Izzet Staticaster) and especially [Zhur-Taa Druid](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Zhur-Taa Druid).  
  
Really though, he is the ultimate best friend of [Royal Assassin](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Royal Assassin).

Posted By: homicidalgecko (6/30/2013 1:01:23 AM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
Worst case scenario? Tap himself and untap your [gelectrode](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=gelectrode) or just a land. Best case, his +1 removes the blocker you needed and you win.  
  
Some random chance is quite acceptable. You simply have to manipulate it that it's not so bad. On average you'll get 2.5 turns. If you round down to 2 turns and have something like [Contagion Engine](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Contagion Engine) or i[nexorable tide](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=nexorable tide) then you can shoot up to 6 counters without any issue. This means that with a mere 2 card combo you'll almost have infinite turns on average; for 4 mana per turn.  
  
If you're going to net "infinite turns", this is by far the most fair/fun way to do it.
posts.html:

Posted By: 4649matt (6/18/2013 5:53:08 AM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
@erikstangents  
While he can do that with timevault, [Tezzeret the Seeker](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Tezzeret the Seeker) can do it too - but not only that, he can tutor it out of your deck first. Since [time vault](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=time vault) is restricted in vintage, it is important to be able to tutor for it reliably. On top of that, it means tezzeret is actually a win-con by himself only requiring you to untap with him (and time vault not being destroyed).  
  
As for this card, I think it's pretty good, but not amazing. I'm glad it is a more balanced planeswalker though meaning casual players can enjoy it too, and it's still good enough to potentially see use in a competitive deck.  
  
The main things about this card that I like/don't like:  
Dislike:  
1) Tapping things doesn't do much because they will untap on their next turn.  
2) His -2 is just a lightning bolt. I was hoping for a 'divided as you choose' sort of thing, but maybe that would be too strong (though it is -2...).  
Like:  
1) Blue/Red ramp anyone?  
2) Not broken.  
3) Ga... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)

While he can do that with timevault, Tezzeret the Seeker can do it too - but not only that, he can tutor it out of your deck first. On top of that, it means tezzeret is actually a win-con by himself only requiring you to untap with him (and time vault not being destroyed).

As for this card, I think it's pretty good, but not amazing. I'm glad it is a more balanced planeswalker though meaning casual players can enjoy it too, and it's still good enough to potentially see use in a competitive deck.

2) His -2 is just a lightning bolt. I was hoping for a 'divided as you choose' sort of thing, but maybe that would be too strong (though it is -2...).
